docs.lead_paragraph: Retired football players face a decision on whether to accept the proposed deal, to opt out and perhaps sue the league for more or to object and possibly appeal the settlement.

headline.seo: N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Divides Former Players
headline.main: For Retirees, Decision on Concussion Settlement Will Not Be a Simple One
headline.print_headline: For Retirees, Decision on Concussion Settlement Will Not Be a Simple One

docs.abstract: Analysis; 4,500 retired NFL players who have sued league for hiding dangers of concussion from them will soon have to make decision to accept or reject proposed deal; litigants must first weigh host of arguments and consider their health and financial needs.
docs.snippet: Retired football players face a decision on whether to accept the proposed deal, to opt out and perhaps sue the league for more or to object and possibly appeal the settlement.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of low- and moderate-income Americans could find themselves without health insurance if a destructive decision by an appellate court is not reversed.
docs.abstract: Editorial warns that millions of low- and moderate-income people who signed up for health insurance with help of federal tax-credit subsidies could find themselves without coverage or with big premium bills if federal appeals court decision is not reversed; contends decision would be crippling blow to ability of health care reform law to reduce ranks of uninsured with grievous consequences for vulnerable customers.
docs.snippet: Millions of low- and moderate-income Americans could find themselves without health insurance if a destructive decision by an appellate court is not reversed.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: While researchers pursue high-cost remedies for rare ailments, development of broadly useful drugs like antibiotics is lagging.

headline.main: A Dearth in Innovation for Key Drugs
headline.print_headline: A Dearth in Innovation for Key Drugs

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column; pharmaceutical industry seems uninterested in developing drugs to combat potential disaster, even as World Health Organization warns of possible 'post-antibiotic era' and antibiotic-resistant infections sicken more than two million Americans each year; economics of drug development seem counter to securing highest levels of public health.
docs.snippet: While researchers pursue high-cost remedies for rare ailments, development of broadly useful drugs like antibiotics is lagging.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court may ultimately resolve the conflicting decisions of two federal appeals courts, but that’s just one option among many.

headline.main: After Health Law Rulings, Here Are Possible Next Steps

docs.snippet: The Supreme Court may ultimately resolve the conflicting decisions of two federal appeals courts, but that’s just one option among many.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The administration will not reconsider its Affordable Care Act regulations until the conflicting cases are resolved.

headline.main: Rulings on Health Law Are Far From Last Word

docs.snippet: The administration will not reconsider its Affordable Care Act regulations until the conflicting cases are resolved.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: One federal appeals court panel ruled that the federal government could not subsidize coverage bought by people on the federal insurance exchange. Another said the opposite.

headline.main: New Questions on Health Law as Rulings on Subsidies Differ
headline.print_headline: New Questions on Health Law as Courts Differ on Subsidies

docs.abstract: Two federal appeals court panels issue conflicting rulings on whether government can subsidize health insurance premiums for millions of Americans, raising more questions about future of health care reform law; contradictory rulings will have no immediate impact on consumers but could inject uncertainty and turmoil into health insurance markets as Obama administration firms up plans for next open enrollment season.
docs.snippet: One federal appeals court panel ruled that the federal government could not subsidize coverage bought by people on the federal insurance exchange. Another said the opposite.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is developing a method for religious organizations opposed to contraception coverage under the Affordable Care Act to opt out of providing the coverage in their health plans without filling out a form.

headline.main: Obama Government Looks to Satisfy Religious Groups on Obamacare
headline.print_headline: Obama Government Looks to Satisfy Religious Groups on Obamacare

docs.snippet: The Obama administration is developing a method for religious organizations opposed to contraception coverage under the Affordable Care Act to opt out of providing the coverage in their health plans without filling out a form.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. judges have their work cut out for them untangling a legal knot created on Tuesday when two federal appeals courts released conflicting rulings hours apart going to the heart of the role the federal government will play in Obamacare.

headline.main: Latest Obamacare Legal Knot Won't Be Easy to Untangle
headline.print_headline: Latest Obamacare Legal Knot Won't Be Easy to Untangle

docs.snippet: U.S. judges have their work cut out for them untangling a legal knot created on Tuesday when two federal appeals courts released conflicting rulings hours apart going to the heart of the role the federal government will play in Obamacare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional investigators using fake identities were able to obtain taxpayer-subsidized health insurance under President Barack Obama's law, according to testimony to be delivered Wednesday.

headline.main: Undercover Probe Finds Health Law Failings
headline.print_headline: Undercover Probe Finds Health Law Failings

docs.snippet: Congressional investigators using fake identities were able to obtain taxpayer-subsidized health insurance under President Barack Obama's law, according to testimony to be delivered Wednesday.
